summary: Finding that a settlement agreement, entered into long after a work’s creation, stipulating that a work was created for hire constitutes “any agreement to the contrary” under 17 U.S.C. § 304(c)
Finding that a new agreement that revoked the original grant and re-issued rights in the works to the appellee was valid

Finding that neither the plain language nor legislative intent of the Copyright Act precluded authors and their statutory successors from losing the right to terminate a pre-1978 grant by renegotiating it

Holding a later agreement transferring rights before a termination vested did not preclude termination since such an assignment would be void as an “agreement to the contrary” pursuant to 17 U.S.C. § 304(c)
